channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Man Rushes Ilhan Omar at Minneapolis Town Hall and Sprays Her
item.description: A man who had been sitting in the front row rushed at the Democratic representative and sprayed her with a strong-smelling liquid. He was removed by security and later booked into jail.
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault, Lauren McCarthy and Ashley Ahn
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man rushed toward Representative Ilhan Omar, Democrat of Minnesota, and sprayed liquid on her on Tuesday night in Minneapolis. Security officials tackled him.

item.title: D.H.S. Review Does Not Say Pretti Brandished Gun, As Noem Claimed
item.description: An initial report from an internal agency watchdog says the Minneapolis man was shot by law enforcement after resisting arrest, but makes no mention of the allegations leveled by a Trump administration official.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo, Alexandra Berzon and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial at the site where Alex Pretti was shot and killed by federal agents during an immigration enforcement operation.

item.title: Judge Temporarily Blocks Deportation of 5-Year-Old Detained by ICE in Minnesota
item.description: An image of the boy, wearing a Spider-Man backpack as he was detained by federal agents, became a symbol of the immigration crackdown in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protester holding an artwork of Liam Conejo Ramos in Portland, Maine, last week.

item.title: Republicans Shift Tone After Killings, Criticizing Trump’s Immigration Push
item.description: With the president signaling a pivot in his crackdown, G.O.P. lawmakers have felt freer to express concern. But it’s not clear what they are willing to do about it.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Republicans in Congress have starkly shifted their tone on the Trump administration’s aggressive immigration crackdown, conceding that something must change.

item.title: Noem’s Handling of Shooting Put Her in Trump’s Penalty Box, but Just Briefly
item.description: Kristi Noem’s aggressiveness has sometimes given President Trump heartburn. She got a rebuke after a second killing by federal immigration agents but soon seemed to be back in his good graces.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater, Hamed Aleaziz and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The fatal shooting in Minnesota over the weekend was the latest episode in which high-profile efforts by Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, on behalf of President Trump’s policies have drawn intense criticism.

item.title: Democrats Push to Impeach DHS Secretary Kristi Noem After Minneapolis Shooting
item.description: Following the fatal shooting in Minneapolis, a drive to impeach the homeland security secretary has drawn dozens more Democratic supporters, including the party’s top three leaders.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Representatives Pete Aguilar, Democrat of California and the Democratic Caucus chair; Hakeem Jeffries, Democrat of New York and the minority leader; and Katherine Clark, Democrat of Massachusetts and the minority whip, at a news conference in Washington this month.

item.title: Dozens Arrested After Anti-ICE Protest at a Manhattan Hilton
item.description: The demonstration at the TriBeCa hotel followed a similar targeting of a Hilton property in Minneapolis on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Ed Shanahan and Olivia Bensimon
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: Anti-ICE protesters and guests filled the lobby of a Hilton Garden Inn in Manhattan on Tuesday evening.

item.title: Why Did the Trump Administration Silence Bovino on Social Media?
item.description: When the border chief got yanked from Minnesota, he lost access to his X account, too.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: Gregory Bovino speaking in Minneapolis last week.

item.title: Trump Threatens to Pull U.S. Help From Iraq if Former Leader Returns
item.description: Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a former prime minister, has been nominated to the post by the main Shiite Muslim bloc in the Iraqi Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Thaier Al-Sudani/Reuters
item.media:description: Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a former prime minister of Iraq, at a polling station in Baghdad in November.

item.title: Judge Revives Wind Farm That Trump Halted Off Martha’s Vineyard
item.description: The project, known as Vineyard Wind, was already 95 percent complete when the Trump administration ordered construction to stop.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Randi Baird for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Vineyard wind farm in the Atlantic Ocean off Martha’s Vineyard, Mass.

item.title: U.S. Expects to Finish Review of Epstein Files Soon, Bondi Says
item.description: By law, the government was required to release its files on Jeffrey Epstein in December. Now the attorney general said they will be out “in the near term.”
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Attorney General Pam Bondi said in a filing that the Justice Department’s efforts to release the Epstein files involved hundreds of lawyers and other staff members.

item.title: As Trump Promotes Economy in Iowa, Many Residents Feel Pain
item.description: Farmers are critical to Iowa’s economy. They have been battered by President Trump’s tariffs and are not experiencing the “golden age” that the president promised.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump visited a restaurant on Tuesday in Davenport, Iowa. The state has been struggling under his economic policies.

item.title: Democrats Restore Minnesota House to Even Split Amid Immigration Turmoil
item.description: In special elections on Tuesday, Democrats won two left-leaning districts, preventing Republicans from holding a majority in the State House of Representatives.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Liam James Doyle for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Minnesota House of Representatives at the Capitol in St. Paul.

item.title: These Foods Might Lower Cancer Risk
item.description: Decades of research suggests that your diet can influence the risk of various cancers. Here’s what we know.
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.media:credit: Bobbi Lin for The New York Times

item.title: Safety Board Blames F.A.A. For Multiple Failures in D.C. Crash
item.description: The National Transportation Safety Board found the probable causes of the midair collision last year included poorly designed flight routes and ignored warnings about risks.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Kate Kelly
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jennifer Homendy, the National Transportation Safety Board chairwoman, speaking after the crash at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport last year. The board plans to publish a full report on the crash.

item.title: She’s the Face of Trump’s Aviation Safety Board, and She’s a Democrat
item.description: Jennifer Homendy, the outspoken chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board, is reclaiming the spotlight at a meeting on Tuesday about the Washington, D.C., crash that killed 67.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jennifer Homendy, the chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board, reconvening a hearing in July on the midair collision above Washington.

item.title: Troop Casualties in Ukraine War Near 2 Million, Study Finds
item.description: The number of deaths, injuries and missing is approaching a grim milestone after nearly four years of fighting.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of a Ukrainian soldier in Uzhhorod, Ukraine, last year. The latest accounting of casualties came after talks among Russian, Ukrainian and American officials ended on Saturday on a rare positive note.

item.title: Another Weekend Winter Storm? Forecast Details and Updates.
item.description: Meteorologists are watching another storm that could hit the East Coast this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: The forecast could change before the weekend, but it’s looking more likely that another winter storm will affect part of the East Coast.

item.title: Storm Tests Mamdani as Dangerous Cold Grips New York
item.description: The death toll from the storm has risen to 10. As it emerged that some of the dead had prior contact with social service workers, Mayor Zohran Mamdani vowed to do more to get people into shelters.
item.dc:creator: Dana Rubinstein and Mihir Zaveri
item.media:credit: Kent J. Edwards for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zohran Mamdani said on Tuesday that instituting Code Blue rules was not enough, saying that when “the cold is this deadly, we need to meet the moment.”

item.title: Spain Offers Undocumented Migrants a Legal Way to Stay
item.description: The measure, unexpectedly approved, comes as other countries are cracking down on immigration.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Venezuelan food stall in Madrid in early January. The measure passed on Tuesday will apply to undocumented migrants already living in Spain, many of whom are from Latin America.

item.title: Bari Weiss Urges CBS News to Think Like a ‘Start-Up’
item.description: “We are not producing a product enough people want,” Ms. Weiss told employees at her first all-staff meeting at the network.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Leigh Vogel/Getty Images
item.media:description: Bari Weiss was appointed editor in chief of CBS News last year.

item.title: Southwest Begins Assigned Seating, Scrapping a Signature Quirk
item.description: The airline said its new policy, rolled out on Tuesday, responded to passengers’ preferences, but some customers said the scramble was part of the charm.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Jacob Langston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Southwest Airlines commemorated the end of its longstanding open-seating policy with a celebration on Tuesday morning at Orlando International Airport.

item.title: The Rise and Fall of South Korean First Lady Kim Keon Hee
item.description: Kim Keon Hee was unlike any presidential spouse South Korea had seen. Her downfall, on corruption charges, came after her husband declared martial law.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images
item.media:description: Kim Keon Hee, South Korea’s former first lady, arrived for her first hearing on corruption charges at Seoul Central District Court in September.

item.title: Who Decides When a Home Is Safe? A California Bill Says Science, Not Insurers.
item.description: Following a Times investigation, a state lawmaker is proposing the first health-based standards for assessing smoke contamination after wildfires.
item.dc:creator: Rukmini Callimachi and Blacki Migliozzi
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Days after the devastating Eaton fire last year, the Los Angeles community of Altadena was still smoldering.

item.title: Gladys West, Unsung Figure in Development of GPS, Dies at 95
item.description: As a Navy mathematician in the 1950s and beyond, she played an unheralded but foundational role in making possible the global satellite-based mapping system.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: Should Iran’s Executioners Go Unpunished?
item.description: It’s left to the United States to impose meaningful consequences on the Iranian regime for one of the worst atrocities of this century.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Immigration Enforcement Is Unavoidably Upsetting. But This Is Something Else.
item.description: Is this really the only way to enforce the law?
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Sam Whitney/The New York Times

item.title: Former French Senator Convicted of Drugging a Colleague, Intending to Assault Her
item.description: The trial took on special resonance in France, a year after a court found Dominique Pelicot and dozens of other men guilty of raping Gisèle Pelicot while she was sedated.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Thomas Padilla/Associated Press
item.media:description: Joël Guerriau, a former French senator, arriving at court with his lawyers in Paris on Monday.

item.title: Tails of the City: San Francisco’s Latest Animal Sensation Is a Mountain Lion
item.description: The 2-year-old male was safely captured after he got stuck between two apartment buildings.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight

item.title: Man Went on ‘Trial Run’ Before Killing 4 Homeless Men, Prosecutors Say
item.description: Randy Rodriguez Santos faces four murder charges for the beating deaths of homeless men in Manhattan’s Chinatown in 2019. The killings left the city’s homeless population on edge.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Rashid Umar Abbasi
item.media:description: A lawyer for Randy Rodriguez Santos, the man on trial, addressed Mr. Santos’s schizophrenia diagnosis in court.
